Scalable synthesis of a new {P2Mo18O62}-modified CuI/CuII-based metal–organic complex for multi-center synergistic catalysis of benzyl alcohol to benzoic acid Xiaoyan Zhang Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Investigation Na Xu Writing – review & editing Validation Funding acquisition Xiaohui Liu Validation Formal analysis Data curation Yanyan Guo Validation Methodology Data curation Zuhao Shang Software Methodology Investigation Xiuli Wang Writing – review & editing Validation Funding acquisition ⁎ College of Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Bohai University, Liaoning Professional Technology Innovation Center of Liaoning Province for Conversion Materials of Solar Cell, Jinzhou 121013, PR China College of Chemistry and Materials Engineering Bohai University Liaoning Professional Technology Innovation Center of Liaoning Province for Conversion Materials of Solar Cell Jinzhou 121013 PR China College of Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Bohai University, Liaoning Professional Technology Innovation Center of Liaoning Province for Conversion Materials of Solar Cell, Jinzhou 121013, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. The scalable production of high-efficiency catalysts derived from polyoxometalates (POMs) is critically significant for advancing the catalysis sector. Herein, the synthesis of a new [P2Mo18O62]6– ({P2Mo18})-based metal–organic complex, (CuI L 2)11[(CuII L 2Cl)(P2Mo18O62)2]·2L·0.5H2O (L = benzimidazole) (1), was achieved on a large scale using the one-pot method, and the complex was systematically characterized. Complex 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular framework by hydrogen bonding interactions between [CuII 0.5 LCl0.5]-decorated {P2Mo18} anions and {CuI L 2} metal–organic subunits. Benzyl alcohol (BA) was efficiently oxidized to benzoic acid (BZA) with complex 1 as a stable heterogeneous catalyst, exhibiting a remarkable conversion rate of nearly 100 % and an outstanding selectivity of 99.47 %. Notably, the catalytic system exhibits outstanding scalability, with no significant decrease in conversion and selectivity after a 20-fold increase in reaction scale. The remarkable efficiency is attributable to the unique multi-center synergistic catalytic mechanism of CuI, CuII, and MoVI within complex 1. These findings could provide significant insights into the rational design and synthesis of POMs-based catalytic materials with enhanced catalytic efficiency. Graphical abstract The synthesis of a new {P2Mo18O62}-based metal–organic complex featuring CuI/CuII centers has been successfully achieved on a gram scale, showcasing its efficacy in multi-centers synergistic catalysis for the conversion of benzyl alcohol to benzoic acid. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phosphomolybdates Scalable synthesis Metal-organic complexes Synergistic catalysis Oxidation of benzyl alcohol Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Polyoxometalates (POMs) represent a distinct class of metal-oxygen cluster nanomaterials that are renowned for their structural diversity and exceptional properties [1-5]. These attributes have garnered POMs extensive utility across various domains, including materials science, catalysis, magnetism, optics, electronics, and pharmaceutical chemistry [6-14]. The use in catalysis is particularly noteworthy, as POMs and their derivatives can act as both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts, promoting a wide range of chemical transformations, including oxidation, reduction, and polymerization reactions [15-21]. More importantly, the large-scale synthesis of new POM-derived crystalline catalysts is crucial for their application in industrial processes, which is still a formidable challenge. Phosphomolybdates, a substantial subset of POMs, are distinguished by their unique structural characteristics, and broad catalytic utility, as exemplified by species such as [P2Mo5O23]6–, [P4Mo6O31]12–, [PMo12O40]3–, [P2Mo18O62]6– [22-28]. Of particular interest is the Wells-Dawson type phosphomolybdate [P2Mo18O62]6– (abbreviated as {P2Mo18}), which boasts a surface with up to 54 oxygen atoms. The inherent characteristic enables a wide range of bridging coordination modes with metal–organic units, thereby facilitating the construction of structurally diverse POM-based metal–organic complexes (POMOCs) [29,30]. POMOCs possess multiple metal active centers that function as potential catalytic sites for synergistic catalysis [13,19]. Notably, traditional metal ions like CeIII, EuIII, RhII, and PbII have been used in the synthesis of {P2Mo18}-based complexes, transition metal ions, particularly copper ions (CuI or CuII), offer versatility, cost-effectiveness, and high catalytic activity [27,31-35]. Additionally, copper ions are capable of adopting both saturated and unsaturated coordination geometries, with the unsaturated form being particularly conducive to catalytic processes. This flexibility in coordination allows for a wide array of design possibilities for novel POMOCs, each with the potential for unique structures and exceptional properties [36,37]. The synthesis of POMOCs based on {P2Mo18} is significantly influenced by the choice of organic ligands. The benzimidazole is distinguished by its rigidity and capacity to act as a superior structure-directing agent, which provides a π-electron framework and dual nitrogen coordination sites, enabling the creation of complex architectures [38-40]. Moreover, the oxygen atoms present on the {P2Mo18} cluster can function as hydrogen bond acceptors, while the nitrogen atoms of benzimidazole ligands can act as hydrogen bond donors, thereby enhancing the formation of complex, higher-order structures. Therefore, POMOCs fabricated through the assembly of Cun+ ions (n = 1 or 2), {P2Mo18} clusters, and benzimidazole ligands are highly sought-after catalysts, as they have the potential to host multiple active sites. In our work, we employed an expedited one-pot synthetic strategy to achieve the gram–scale fabrication of a benzimidazole-ligated POMOC, (CuI L 2)11[(CuII L 2Cl)(P2Mo18O62)2]·2L·0.5H2O (L = benzimidazole) (1). The intricate architecture of complex 1 harbors multiple active sites, which converge to activate a refined multi-center synergistic catalytic mechanism. This interplay involves a synergy of CuI, CuII, and MoVI centers, their synergistic efforts enhancing catalytic efficiency. This efficacy is manifested in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BA) to benzaldehyde (BZA), where complex 1 facilitates a near-quantitative conversion of approximately 100 % with an exceptional selectivity of 99.47 %. Notably, the catalytic reaction exhibits remarkable scalability, maintaining excellent catalytic performance throughout a 20-fold increase in scale. Additionally, the comprehensive characterization of complex 1 was achieved through a battery of analytical techniques including single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared spectroscopy (IR), thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthetic procedure of complex 1 A mixture of Na2MoO4·2H2O (0.500 g, 2.067 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.200 g, 1.173 mmol), 85 % H3PO4 (0.54 mL, 10 mmol), ligand L (0.118 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in a mixed solution of EtOH/H2O (6 mL, v:v = 1:5). The mixture was stirred for 2.5 h at room temperature, and then the pH was adjusted to about 2.10 using 1 M HCl and 1 M NaOH solutions. Subsequently, the mixture was put into a 25 mL Teflon reactor and heated to 160 °C for 4 days. The dark blue crystals were isolated when the reactor was allowed to cool to ambient temperature. The yield of crystals obtained was 68.40 % based on Mo. The characteristic peak analysis was performed on an IR spectrophotometer (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3451(m), 3279(s), 3100(m), 2361(w), 1618(m), 1494(s), 1461(w), 1403(s), 1302(w), 1246(s), 1195(s), 1109(w), 1133(m), 1064(s), 1009(w), 937(s), 859(m), 807(s), 738(s), 615(m), 547(w). 2.2 General procedure for the catalytic oxidation of BA The substrate of BA (0.5 mmol), complex 1 (8 mg, 8.5 × 10–4 mmol), CH3CN (1 mL), and tert‑butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, 70 % aqueous solution, 300 μL, 2.16 mmol) were added into the sealed reaction vessel and agitated for 9 h under 70 °C. The reaction products of benzaldehyde (BAD) and BZA were monitored by gas chromatography (GC) using naphthalene as the internal standard. The catalyst after the catalytic reaction was successively washed with CH3CN, air-dried, and then employed in the subsequent reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of complex 1 To fabricate various POM-based materials with potential catalytic applications under controlled conditions, herein, we employed a simple molybdenum source Na2MoO4·2H2O as the starting precursor reacted with CuCl2·2H2O, ligand L, and H3PO4 in an acidic system under hydrothermal conditions. It is axiomatic that pH value is a pivotal factor in the assembly process of POM-based materials, a dark blue rod-like complex 1 was synthesized reproducibly within a pH range of 1.97–2.56, with the highest yield achieved at pH = 2.10. More importantly, an expanded synthesis experiment was conducted, even after quadrupling the amount of reactants under the original synthesis conditions, complex 1 (∼1.2 g) could still be obtained, indicating the feasibility of large–scale synthesis (Fig. S1). 3.2 Crystal structure description of complex 1 Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/m. Complex 1 exhibits a discrete structure mainly composed of one [(CuII 0.5 LCl0.5)(P2Mo18O62)]5.5– anion (abbr. {CuII 0.5-P2Mo18}, Fig. 1 a) and five and a half {CuI L 2} subunits (Fig. 1b). Especially, 1 contains six crystallographically independent Cu ions, which exhibit two distinct coordination modes (Fig. 1c). The CuII(1) ion is characterized by a saturated hexa-coordinate geometry, with coordination to four μ 2 O atoms of the {P2Mo18} anion, one N atom from the ligand L, and one Cl− ion (Fig. 2 a). In contrast, the additional CuI ions are unsaturated coordination modes, engaging with two N atoms from two L ligands to constitute {CuI L 2} metal–organic subunits with diverse coordination orientations (Fig. 2b−d). This unique coordination mode offers numerous potential active sites for the catalytic reaction. Table S1 summarizes the detailed crystallographic data of 1. The selected bond length and bond angle information are listed in Tables S2 and S3. Furthermore, the valence states of Cu and Mo atoms were determined using bond valence sum (BVS) in Table S4 and subsequently validated through XPS (Figs. 3 d and S4a). The results showed that the hexa-coordinate Cu ion is in the +II oxidation state, while the di-coordinate Cu ions are in the +I oxidation state. The potential hydrogen bonding interaction between the oxygen atoms on the surface of the {P2Mo18} anions and the N atoms of the ligand L allows for the expansion of 1 from a discrete structure into a high-dimensional supramolecular architecture. Initially, the {CuII 0.5-P2Mo18} subunits (Fig. 2a) are linked to the {CuI L 2} subunits (Fig. 2b) through two kinds of hydrogen bonding interaction N(14)−H(14)···O(4) and N(16)−H(16)···O(6) to form a 1D chain (Fig. S2a). Subsequently, the 1D chain is extended to a “V”-type 2D network through the hydrogen bonding interaction of N(15)−H(15A)···O(10) between {CuII 0.5-P2Mo18} subunits and {CuI L 2} subunits (Figs. 2c, e and S2b). Ultimately, a 3D supramolecular framework is formed by the hydrogen bonds of N(1)−H(1)···O(11) and N(13)−H(13)···O(33) (Figs. 2d, f and S2c). A detailed summary of the hydrogen bonding interactions is provided in Table S5. 3.3 Characterizations The structure, thermal stability, surface morphology, elemental composition, and electronic state of the synthesized complex 1 were characterized by PXRD, IR, TG, SEM, EDS, and XPS. The PXRD patterns indicate a strong correlation between the experimental and simulated data for complex 1, affirming its high crystalline quality and phase purity (Fig. 3a). The IR spectrum of 1 was recorded between 4000 and 500 cm−1 (Fig. 3b). The characteristic peaks located at 3279 and 1618 cm−1 are attributed to ν(O–H) stretching and bending vibrations of H2O molecules [41]. The characteristic peaks of ν(Mo=Ot) and ν(Mo–Ob) vibrations appear at 937, 807, and 738 cm−1, whereas the characteristic peaks at 1064 and 1109 cm−1 are attributed to ν(P–O) [42-44]. The peak located at 1494 cm−1 is attributed to ν(C–N) vibrations [45]. According to the TG curve in Fig. 3c, complex 1 undergoes a three-step weight loss from 25 °C to 800 °C. The initial weight loss of 2.60 % (calcd. 2.60 %), observed upon heating from 25 °C to 170 °C, was attributed to the loss of 0.5 lattice water molecules and two L ligands. The second stage of weight loss occurred within the temperature range of 170 °C to 470 °C, exhibiting a 15.91 % mass decrement (calcd. 15.89 %), which is attributed to the decomposition of five {CuL 2} subunits. Subsequently, the third weight loss of 33.03 % (calcd. 33.02 %) indicated the structural collapse of the complex. The SEM image reveals that 1 exhibits an orderly rod-like crystalline morphology, while EDS analysis confirms the uniform distribution of constituent elements (Fig. S3). In addition, the XPS was conducted to elucidate the chemical states of Cu, Mo, P, and Cl elements in complex 1. The results indicated that CuI ions and CuII ions coexist in 1. The CuI ions peaks were observed at binding energies of 953.64 eV and 933.73 eV, whereas the CuII ions peaks were detected at 956.13 eV and 935.89 eV (Fig. 3d) [46]. Concurrently, the analysis confirmed that the Mo ions were in a +VI oxidation state, with binding energies situated at 235.28 eV and 232.13 eV (Fig. S4a), while the binding energies around 133.36 eV correspond to the P ions in the phosphate group (Fig. S4b) [47,48]. The binding energies at approximately 198.41 and 200.01 eV further confirm the presence of Cl− ions in complex 1 (Fig. S4c) [49]. 3.4 Selective catalytic oxidation of BA The catalytic activity of complex 1 as a catalyst was investigated by using BA oxidation as a model reaction (Table 1). Initially, the optimal reaction parameters were systematically investigated, as detailed in Tables S6–S10. These parameters included the choice of solvent, solvent volume, catalyst loading, oxidant concentration, and reaction temperature. Initially, the catalytic efficacy of the reaction was investigated in different solvents, such as acetonitrile (CH3CN), water (H2O), ethanol (EtOH), dichloromethane (CH2Cl2), acetone, and 1,4-dioxane. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the use of CH3CN as the solvent yielded a remarkable conversion of BA to 99.38 % with selectivity for BZA of 99.14 %, surpassing the performance observed with other solvents. The manipulation of solvent volume further fine-tuned the conversion of BA to BZA, with the most favorable results obtained using 1 mL of CH3CN (Fig. 4b). Investigation into the impact of catalyst dosage revealed that 8 mg of complex 1 provided the highest catalytic efficacy (Fig. 4c). The influence of the oxidant TBHP was also examined. As the volume of TBHP was incremented from 100 μL to 200 μL, a notable increase in the conversion of BA to 98.12 % was observed, accompanied by a selectivity for BZA of 95.94 %. A further increase to 300 μL of TBHP led to an almost complete conversion of BA, with selectivity for BZA rising to 99.47 %. However, any additional increase in the TBHP volume did not significantly enhance the catalytic performance, establishing 300 μL as the optimal dosage for the oxidant. (Fig. 4d). The temperature dependence of the catalytic system, as illustrated in Fig. S5, indicated that 70 °C was the most favorable reaction temperature. Additionally, the conversion of BA and the selectivity for BZA continued to improve with the extension of reaction time, culminating in exceptional efficiency after 9 h (Fig. S6). Based on the aforementioned results, the optimal reaction conditions were established as follows: 8 mg (0.85 μmol) catalyst, 300 μL (2.16 mmol) TBHP, 1 mL CH3CN, 70 °C, and 9 h. Under these optimal conditions, the conversion of BA approached 100 %, with a selectivity for BZA exceeding 99.47 % (Table 1, entry 1), showcasing the high efficiency and selectivity of the catalytic system. The remarkable efficiency of catalyst 1 in achieving high conversion and selectivity has prompted an investigation into its scalability for catalytic reactions (Table S11). Under optimized conditions, the scale of the catalytic reaction was progressively increased to 5-fold, 10-fold, 15-fold, and 20-fold its original scale, with the conversion of BA maintained above 99 % and the selectivity for BZA also sustained above 97 % throughout this process (Fig. 5 ). These results adequately demonstrate the tremendous potential of catalyst 1 for large–scale practical applications, offering a promising outlook for potential industrial production. Given catalyst 1 has excellent catalytic oxidation ability for the oxidation of BA, a series of control experiments were carried out to further explore the potential catalytic active sites and catalytic mechanism. In the absence of 1, the conversion of BA was only 40.22 %, and the selectivity of BZA was 50.71 % (Table 1 , entry 2). The critical role of the oxidant in the catalytic system was further underscored by the observation that in the absence of TBHP, the conversion of BA was significantly diminished to 17.75 %, despite a selectivity for BZA of 78.70 % (Table 1, entry 3). The result indicates an important interaction between the catalyst and TBHP, which promotes the catalytic reaction. To analyze the effect of catalytic active sites on the catalytic oxidation of BA, the individual components Na2MoO4·2H2O, CuCl, CuCl2·2H2O, and ligand L were employed as catalysts for comparison experiments, the conversion rates of BA were 64.32 %, 91.12 %, 65.52 %, and 20.27 %, respectively, with corresponding selectivities for BZA of 40.14%, 91.07 %, 59.36 %, and 13.77 %, respectively (Table 1, entries 4–7). Besides, the use of a physical mixture of Na2MoO4·2H2O/CuCl2·2H2O/L showed minimal impact on the conversion of BA and the selectivity of BZA (Table 1, entry 8). The conversion of BA was enhanced to 73.67 % when the physical mixture of Na2MoO4·2H2O/CuCl/L was used, as compared to Table 1, entry 8 (Table 1, entry 9). This indicates that CuI ions play an important role in the catalytic oxidation process of BA. The catalytic efficiency was further enhanced when the mixture of Na2MoO4·2H2O/CuCl2·2H2O/CuCl/L functions as a catalyst (Table 1, entry 10). The above results showed that the three metal centers (CuI, CuII, and MoVI) of 1 may be the active sites for catalyzing the oxidation of BA, and the synergistic effect of the catalytic sites was conducive to the catalytic reaction. To gain insights into the kinetic aspects of the catalytic oxidation of BA, kinetic studies were conducted. The conversion of BA and the natural logarithm of the ratio of the concentration at the time to the initial concentration (ln(Ct/C0)) were plotted against reaction time at 70 °C, as presented in Fig. S7. The data revealed that the kinetic profile adhered to a pseudo-first-order model, yielding a reaction rate constant of 0.5458 h‒1. Subsequently, a hot filtration experiment was performed to assess the heterogeneous nature of complex 1. As illustrated in Fig. 6 a, following centrifugation of the catalyst after 1 hour, only a marginal increase in BA conversion was observed over the subsequent 8 h, indicative of the heterogeneity of 1. Moreover, complex 1 demonstrated excellent recyclability, maintaining a conversion rate of BA at 94.03 % and a selectivity for BZA at 95.67 % throughout five consecutive cycles (Fig. 6b). The PXRD patterns and IR spectra of 1 after the catalytic reaction were tested to confirm the structural stability (Figs. 6c and d). Additionally, the XPS analysis of the oxidation states of Cu and Mo ions of 1 after catalytic reaction showed that the valence states were not altered (Fig. S8), which further confirmed its stability. 3.5 Possible catalytic mechanism The phenomenon of multicenter cooperative catalysis is pivotal in unraveling the intricate mechanisms that underpin the full catalytic cycle. To demystify the complicated pathways involved in the oxidation of BA, a stringent and systematic mechanistic inquiry has been initiated. According to the literature, it is assumed that the oxidation of aromatic alcohols is mediated by oxygen and carbon radicals [34,50,51]. We try to study the effectiveness of these intermediates in the multi-center catalytic process. For this purpose, radical scavengers such as butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) for oxygen radicals and 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-oxide (TEMPO) for carbon radicals were introduced into the reaction system. A detailed analysis of the effects of these scavengers on the overall reaction kinetics and selectivity was carried out to identify the synergistic interactions between catalysts, substrates, and reactive intermediates, thus elucidating the elusive multi-molecular mechanism controlling the oxidation process. As shown in Fig. S9a, the introduction of radical scavengers results in a significant inhibition of BA conversion, signifying the critical involvement of radicals as intermediates in the catalytic cycle. The observation that the impediment to conversion is more pronounced in the presence of the oxygen radical scavenger BHT, compared to the carbon radical scavenger TEMPO, underscores the predominant role of oxygen radicals in the primary stages of BA oxidation. Generally, the catalytic sites of CuI in complex 1 facilitate the activation of TBHP (t-BuOOH) to generate tert‑butyloxy radical (t-BuO•), while CuII sites readily initiate TBHP to produce tert‑butylperoxy radical (t-BuOO•) (Fig. S10) [52,53]. To further substantiate the production of t-BuO• and t-BuOO• radicals within the catalytic system, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy was carried out using N‑tert‑butyl‑α-phenylnitrone (PBN) as a spin-trapping agent. As illustrated in Fig. S9b, when the catalytic system contained only catalyst 1 in the absence of t-BuOOH, no significant signal peaks were detected, indicating that the catalyst requires the presence of t-BuOOH to be activated. Conversely, when the catalytic system contained t-BuOOH but lacked catalyst 1, a faint signal peak was detected, which is ascribed to the formation of the PBN/t-BuOO• spin adduct resulting from the thermal decomposition of t-BuOOH. When both the catalyst and t-BuOOH were present in the catalytic system, a strong sextet signal peak attributed to the PBN-spin adduct was observed [54]. This phenomenon confirms that the interaction between catalyst 1 and TBHP can generate t-BuO• and t-BuOO• radicals, thereby facilitating the progression of the catalytic reaction. The capability of both oxygen radicals to abstract a hydrogen atom from the substrate is instrumental in the formation of the corresponding carbon radical intermediate (routes 1 and 2 in Scheme 1 ). This intermediate serves as a crucial entity that enables the facilitation of the conversion of BA. Furtherly, the formation of the benzyl radical was verified by high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS). TEMPO was added to the catalytic system to quench hydrogen and benzyl radicals. The distinctive peaks observed at m/z = 158.1534 and 262.1794 in the MS spectrum correspond to the formation of TEMPOH and TEMPO-PhCOH, respectively, indicating that TEMPO has trapped H• radicals and benzyl radicals from the catalytic system (Fig. S9c) [55,56]. Moreover, the fact that the radical scavengers did not entirely quench the catalytic activity suggests the concurrent process of alternative nonradical pathways within the system. The catalytic mechanism is hypothesized to involve the interaction between POMs and TBHP, leading to the generation of reactive peroxide species. This hypothesis was corroborated by Raman spectroscopy, which revealed a marked intensification of the peak at 890 cm–1 following the catalytic reaction—a phenomenon attributed to the O–O stretching vibration of peroxide species (Fig. S9d) [57,58]. In Table S12, the control experiments were conducted in the absence of TBHP. The results indicate that the oxidation of BA is inefficient when catalyzed individually by CuCl, CuCl2·2H2O, and Na2MoO4·2H2O, with conversion rates of only 4.13 %, 4.81 %, and 5.95 % respectively. These findings further underscore the synergistic effect of the CuI, CuII, and MoVI active sites in combination with TBHP in the oxidation process of BA. Based on these observations, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed in Scheme 1. The whole catalytic oxidation process encompasses two pathways: a radical pathway initiated by the interaction of CuI (route 1) and CuII sites (route 2) with TBHP, and a nonradical pathway initiated by the MoVI sites (route 3) within POMs under TBHP activation. According to the structural characteristics of 1, the reaction process of each component in the catalytic oxidation of BA was analyzed. (i) The unsaturated coordinated CuI sites in {CuI L 2} moiety of catalyst 1 are oxidized to CuII sites by TBHP. This oxidation step generates t-BuO• radicals and hydroxide ions (OH–). The t-BuO• radicals, which are electron-deficient and reactive, interact with the substrate of BA, abstracting a hydrogen atom to form a carbon radical intermediate. Subsequently, the intermediate is converted to BAD, which is ultimately transformed into the target product, BZA (Fig. S11). (ii) The saturated coordinated CuII sites in the {CuII 0.5-P2Mo18} subunits are reduced to CuI under the action of TBHP. Concurrently, TBHP is converted to t-BuOO• radicals and hydrogen ions (H+), as represented by Fig. S12. After that, the generated t-BuOO• radicals also engage with the BA substrate, facilitating its conversion to the corresponding benzyl radicals, ultimately leading to the formation of BZA. (iii) Upon interaction with TBHP, the active sites of MoVI within POMs generate peroxide intermediates, which undergo a proton transfer process with the substrate, leading to the formation of BZA (Fig. S13). Overall, the synergistic catalysis of CuI, CuII, and MoVI sites in catalyst 1 renders it an efficient catalyst for the oxidation of aromatic alcohols. Evaluation of the catalytic performance of a catalyst is not only based on its efficiency but also on its versatility in various reactions. To explore the broad applicability of catalyst 1, a series of aromatic alcohols with substituents that either donate or withdraw electrons were employed as substrates. The results demonstrated that catalyst 1 exhibited remarkable tolerance towards electron-donating groups, leading to high yields of the corresponding benzoic acids (Table 2 , entries 1–5). However, when electron-withdrawing groups were present, a slight decrease in the yields was observed (Table 2, entries 6–9). The position of the substituents on the aromatic ring also played a significant role in the catalytic efficiency. For substrates with the same substituents, ortho-substituted aromatic alcohols showed lower catalytic activity compared to their meta- and para-substituted counterparts, primarily due to steric hindrance (Table 2, entries 1–3). Moreover, the presence of larger substituents negatively affected the catalytic activity (Table 2, entries 3–5). Hence, catalyst 1 emerges as a remarkable catalyst for the selective oxidation of aromatic alcohols to their corresponding acids, displaying both high tolerance and efficiency across a wide range of substrates with diverse electronic and steric properties. The catalytic performance for the oxidation of BA by various catalysts was summarized in Table S13, showing that complex 1 is significantly more effective in converting BA to BZA than most catalysts reported in the literature. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the synthesis of the {P2Mo18}-derived CuI/CuII-benzimidazole complex (1) on a large scale through a straightforward one-pot process has been realized. This complex exhibits a 3D supramolecular framework, which is formed through intricate hydrogen bonding interactions. The oxidation of BA to BZA is markedly efficient, with a conversion rate approaching completeness and a selectivity of 99.47 %, a process facilitated by the tri-center cooperative action of CuI, CuII, and MoVI within complex 1. Additionally, even after the scale-up of the catalytic reaction, the complex continues to exhibit robust catalytic activity. This multi-center collaborative catalysis is responsible for the exceptional conversion rates and selectivity observed. These findings provide crucial guidance for the rational design and synthesis of POM-based catalytic materials, thereby propelling advancements in the field of catalysis. coredata.dc:description: The scalable production of high-efficiency catalysts derived from polyoxometalates (POMs) is critically significant for advancing the catalysis sector. Herein, the synthesis of a new [P2Mo18O62]6– ({P2Mo18})-based metal–organic complex, (CuI L 2)11[(CuII L 2Cl)(P2Mo18O62)2]·2L·0.5H2O (L = benzimidazole) (1), was achieved on a large scale using the one-pot method, and the complex was systematically characterized. Complex 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular framework by hydrogen bonding interactions between [CuII 0.5 LCl0.5]-decorated {P2Mo18} anions and {CuI L 2} metal–organic subunits. Benzyl alcohol (BA) was efficiently oxidized to benzoic acid (BZA) with complex 1 as a stable heterogeneous catalyst, exhibiting a remarkable conversion rate of nearly 100 % and an outstanding selectivity of 99.47 %. Notably, the catalytic system exhibits outstanding scalability, with no significant decrease in conversion and selectivity after a 20-fold increase in reaction scale. The remarkable efficiency is attributable to the unique multi-center synergistic catalytic mechanism of CuI, CuII, and MoVI within complex 1. These findings could provide significant insights into the rational design and synthesis of POMs-based catalytic materials with enhanced catalytic efficiency.
